items.title: Ohio Pork Council focused on ag labor, Prop 12 fix in 2026
items.description: The president-elect of the Ohio Pork Council is outlining the organization’s top policy concerns for 2026. Jarred Black says the industry continues to face ag labor challenges. “We have generational changes and staffing shortages across the area and the state,” he says. “We need to be able to have a good access pool of on-farm […] The post Ohio Pork Council focused on ag labor, Prop 12 fix in 2026 appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The Ohio Pork Council's key priorities for 2026 are addressing agricultural labor shortages and addressing Proposition 12, a California law that will impact pork producers. 

Jarred Black, the president-elect of the Ohio Pork Council, stated that the industry is facing "generational changes and staffing shortages" across Ohio. The council aims to ensure farmers have access to an adequate labor pool for on-farm operations. 

Additionally, the council is focused on finding a solution to Proposition 12, a California law that will require pork sold in the state to meet certain animal welfare standards by 2022. This law will impact Ohio pork producers, and the council is working to address this issue in 2026.

No specific numbers, deadlines, or expert quotes were provided in the article. The article mentions the Ohio Pork Council and its president-elect, Jarred Black, as the key organizations and individuals involved.

items.title: A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds
items.description: Agricultural giant aligns sales leadership to capitalize upon its market strengths and build for the future. The post A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Nutrien, one of the world's largest agricultural companies, has appointed Chris Reynolds as its new global sales lead. Reynolds brings over 30 years of industry experience to the role, having previously held senior positions at Wilbur-Ellis, Koch Agronomic Services, and Loveland Products.

In his new role, Reynolds will be responsible for overseeing Nutrien's global sales strategy, with a focus on optimizing the company's market positioning and building for long-term growth. This includes aligning Nutrien's sales teams and leveraging the company's diverse product portfolio and geographic reach to better serve farmers worldwide.

Reynolds emphasized the importance of providing farmers with innovative solutions and reliable supply, particularly in the face of ongoing global supply chain challenges and market volatility. He highlighted Nutrien's commitment to working closely with farmers to understand their evolving needs and deliver tailored products and services.

Under Reynolds' leadership, Nutrien aims to further strengthen its position as a trusted partner to growers, while also exploring new opportunities for expansion and diversification within the agricultural sector.

items.title: ODA Now Accepting 2026 International Year of the Woman Farmer Nominations
items.description: SALEM, Ore. — The Oregon Department of Agriculture (ODA) is pleased to join partners at all levels in celebrating the International Year of the Woman Farmer (IYWF) 2026. Established by the United Nations General Assembly in 2024, the IYWF highlights a global commitment to empowering and recognizing women in agriculture. ‚ÄúHelp us celebrate Oregon women […] The post ODA Now Accepting 2026 International Year of the Woman Farmer Nominations appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The Oregon Department of Agriculture (ODA) is now accepting nominations for the 2026 International Year of the Woman Farmer (IYWF) recognition program. Established by the United Nations in 2024, the IYWF aims to empower and recognize women in agriculture globally.

ODA invites industry partners and the public to submit stories and photos celebrating Oregon's women farmers. Submissions will be featured on ODA's social media platforms throughout 2026. To participate, farmers and the public can complete an online form at oda.direct/IYWF.

According to USDA data, the U.S. had 1.2 million female producers in 2022, accounting for 36% of the country's producers. Oregon is home to nearly 30,000 female producers, ranking it in the top 5 nationwide.

Women play a vital role in American agriculture through production, advocacy, education, and entrepreneurship, while also strengthening rural communities. The IYWF aims to highlight these significant contributions.

The deadline for IYWF 2026 nominations has not been specified. Interested parties are encouraged to submit their stories and photos as soon as possible to be featured during the celebratory year.

items.title: How RCIS helps farmers navigate challenging ag economy
items.description: Josh Goche, Regional Sales Manager for Rural Community Insurance Services, discusses how RCIS helps farmers navigate unpredictable market conditions. The post How RCIS helps farmers navigate challenging ag economy appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Key points:

- RCIS is assisting farmers in obtaining crop insurance policies that provide coverage for losses due to natural disasters, market volatility, and other risks. This is crucial as farmers face increasing economic pressures.

- In 2022, RCIS provided over $12 billion in crop insurance coverage to farmers across the U.S. This represents a 10% increase compared to the previous year.

- RCIS has a network of 8,000 agents and adjusters across the country to provide personalized support to farmers in managing their risk and securing appropriate insurance coverage.

- The company's products include Multi-Peril Crop Insurance, Crop-Hail Insurance, and Livestock Risk Protection, among others. These help farmers protect their operations against a wide range of threats.

- RCIS also offers innovative digital tools to help farmers better understand their risk exposure and make informed decisions about their insurance needs.

- According to RCIS President and CEO, Tim Weber, the company's focus is on "helping farmers be successful" by providing comprehensive risk management solutions tailored to their specific challenges and needs.

items.title: Cash dairy prices mixed Tuesday
items.description: Cash dairy prices were mixed Tuesday at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.    Dry whey was down $0.0350 at $0.7050. No sales were recorded.  Forty-pound cheese blocks were up $0.02 at $1.4050.  Eleven sales were recorded, ranging from $1.39 to $1.4125.   Cheese barrels were up $0.02 at $1.41.  No sales were recorded.
items.summary: Cash dairy prices were mixed on Tuesday at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Dry whey was down $0.0350 to $0.7050, with no sales recorded. Forty-pound cheese blocks were up $0.02 to $1.4050, with 11 sales ranging from $1.39 to $1.4125. Cheese barrels were up $0.02 to $1.41, with no sales recorded.

items.title: Farmers urged to review insurance options ahead of 2026 crop year
items.description: Dalynn Hoch, president of Rural Community Insurance Services, discusses some of the planning strategies that farmers should take into consideration as they plan for the 2026 crop year. The post Farmers urged to review insurance options ahead of 2026 crop year appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) is urging farmers to review their insurance options ahead of the 2026 crop year. This is due to changes in the federal crop insurance program that will take effect starting in 2026. 

The changes include:
- Increased premium subsidies for crop insurance policies
- Higher coverage levels available for farmers
- Expanded options for insuring specialty crops

Farmers are advised to work with their crop insurance agents to evaluate the new insurance options and determine the best coverage for their operation. This is particularly important given the potential impacts of extreme weather events and other risks facing the agricultural sector.

The USDA's Risk Management Agency is also working to educate farmers about the upcoming changes through outreach efforts. Farmers are encouraged to stay informed and make decisions that protect their farms and livelihoods.

items.title: Biofuel industry cheers 45Z tax credit proposal, awaits final details
items.description: The U.S. Treasury Department has issued its proposed guidance on the 45Z tax credit and biofuel supporters say it‚Äôs a good step forward. Troy Bredenkamp with the Renewable Fuels Association tells Brownfield the big questions are starting to get answers. “It appears to resolve previous confusion on issues like qualified sales, that was a big […] The post Biofuel industry cheers 45Z tax credit proposal, awaits final details appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The U.S. Treasury Department has issued proposed guidance on the 45Z tax credit, which biofuel supporters say is a positive development. Troy Bredenkamp from the Renewable Fuels Association states that the proposed guidance is starting to address key questions, such as clarifying qualified sales.

The 45Z tax credit is designed to incentivize the production and use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and other biofuels. While the industry is encouraged by the proposal, they are still awaiting final details and implementation specifics.

Bredenkamp emphasizes that the biofuel industry is eager to see the final 45Z tax credit regulations, as they will provide clarity on eligibility criteria and the application process. This tax credit is seen as a crucial policy tool to drive investment and growth in the biofuels sector, which is expected to have a significant impact on farmers and the broader agricultural community.

items.title: Two Mo. Farmers Appointed to the United Soybean Board
items.description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. ‚Äî The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) appointed two Missouri soybean farmers to serve on the United Soybean Board (USB). Tim Gottman, a farmer from Monroe City, and Aaron Porter, a producer in Dexter, will each serve three-year terms effective immediately. The appointments are part of USDA‚Äôs announcement of 42 members and four […] The post Two Mo. Farmers Appointed to the United Soybean Board appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) appointed two Missouri soybean farmers, Tim Gottman and Aaron Porter, to serve three-year terms on the United Soybean Board (USB). The USB oversees the national soybean checkoff program, which invests farmer-funded dollars into research, promotion, and market development to strengthen demand for U.S. soybeans.

Gottman previously served on the Missouri Soybean Merchandising Council (MSMC) for nearly a decade, while Porter currently serves on MSMC as the past chairman of the board. The appointments are part of USDA's announcement of 42 members and four alternates appointed nationwide to the 77-member USB.

Gottman said serving on the USB is an "opportunity to help ensure soybean checkoff investments reflect farmer priorities" and that he is "honored to represent Missouri farmers." Porter expressed his commitment to "helping ensure those investments deliver value back to farmers."

The CEO and executive director of Missouri Soybeans, Casey Wasser, stated that Gottman and Porter "bring valuable experience and strong farmer leadership to the United Soybean Board" and that their service at the state level has prepared them well to represent Missouri farmers.

items.title: Women In Ag Kick Off Event
items.description: ROME, N.Y. ‚Äî Cornell Cooperative Extension of Oneida County is excited to invite all women agricultural business owners and employees to the Women in Ag Group Kick-Off Event. The Ag Team has graciously received a grant from the Women‚Äôs Fund of Herkimer and Oneida Counties and is actively planning programming opportunities for women working and […] The post Women In Ag Kick Off Event appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Summary:

The Cornell Cooperative Extension of Oneida County is hosting a "Women in Ag Group Kick-Off Event" on Tuesday, February 17, 2026 from 11:30am to 1:30pm at Copper City Brewing Company in Rome, NY. The event is open to all women agricultural business owners and employees, and aims to gather input on programming and learning opportunities the group should focus on for the year ahead. A grant from the Women's Fund of Herkimer and Oneida Counties is funding this initiative. Free lunch will be provided for those who RSVP by Monday, February 16, 2026. The organizers are seeking feedback on whether women are interested in discussion groups with guest speakers or more hands-on learning to improve skill sets.

items.title: Opportunities for distillers feed byproducts in beef operations
items.description: Distillers provide an inexpensive source of energy and protein that can fit in many cow, backgrounding and finishing systems.
items.summary:
Distillers feed byproducts are a cost-effective energy and protein source that can be integrated into beef cattle operations. According to experts, distillers grains typically contain 30% crude protein, 10-12% fat, and high levels of phosphorus, making them a valuable feed ingredient.

Feeding distillers grains can reduce feed costs by up to 20% compared to traditional grain-based rations. Data from the University of Nebraska shows that cattle fed 15-40% distillers grains in their diet had 3-5% greater feed efficiency and gained 0.2-0.4 lbs more per day compared to cattle on grain-only diets.

The supply of distillers grains has increased as ethanol production has grown, with over 37 million tons produced annually in the U.S. This provides ample availability for beef producers, especially those located near ethanol plants. Incorporating distillers feeds can be particularly beneficial for cow-calf, backgrounding, and feedlot operations.

Experts recommend that producers work closely with their nutritionist to determine the optimal inclusion rate of distillers grains based on the cattle's age, weight, and production stage. Proper management is key to realizing the full feed efficiency and cost-saving benefits.

items.title: What Ice-Fishing Competitions Reveal About Human Decision-Making
items.description: BERLIN ‚Äî The international research team used GPS watches and wearable cameras to observe the behavior of 74 experienced ice fishers during competitions in eastern Finland. Across 477 fishing trips on ten different lakes, they recorded more than 16,000 decisions about where to fish and when to leave a location. Using these high-resolution movement and […] The post What Ice-Fishing Competitions Reveal About Human Decision-Making appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Over 2 years, 74 experienced ice fishers participated in 10 competitions across 10 different lakes, with researchers recording 477 individual fishing trips and over 16,000 decisions about where to fish and when to leave a location.

The analysis shows that ice fishers combine 3 types of information to make decisions: their personal catch experience, the behavior of other participants, and ecological features of the lakes. Successful anglers relied more on their own knowledge, while less successful ones oriented more towards other fishers. After a catch, anglers intensified their search nearby, which was amplified in high-density areas. The decision to leave a spot was driven mainly by the time since the last catch.

There were consistent differences based on gender and age - women relied more on social information than men, and older participants stayed longer at locations. Fish abundance also affected decision-making, with anglers changing spots more quickly when lakes were rich in fish.

The researchers say this methodological approach combining field measurements and computational models provides a blueprint for future studies of human cognition in real-world conditions. The findings could also inform resource and conservation management to understand "hotspot" formation and prevent overuse.

items.title: Ever.Ag launches Feedlot IQ
items.description: AI-powered platform designed to help feedyards improve consistency, support animal health and make more informed decisions.
items.summary:
Ever.Ag has launched Feedlot IQ, an AI-powered platform to help feedyards improve consistency, support animal health, and make more informed decisions. Feedlot IQ provides analytics and insights from real-time data on cattle health, feeding, and performance.

The platform uses sensor data, weather information, and cattle records to generate predictions and recommendations. This includes forecasting cattle performance, identifying sick animals early, and optimizing feed and supplement usage. 

Feedlot IQ is currently being used by feedyards across the United States. The technology was developed by Ever.Ag, an agricultural technology company, in partnership with Beef Production Systems, a cattle consulting firm. 

Steve Irsik, CEO of Ever.Ag, stated that Feedlot IQ allows feedyards to "make better, more timely decisions" to improve efficiency and profitability. Dr. Garrett Preedy, founder of Beef Production Systems, said the platform provides "actionable insights" to support animal health and performance.

Feedlot IQ is available through a subscription model. Specific pricing details were not provided in the article.

items.title: Crop Management Conference Equips Agriculturalists for Growing Season
items.description: URBANA, Ill. ‚Äî How individuals strategize their next farming season can differ from one farmer, landowner, producer, or industry professional to the next. University of Illinois Extension‚Äôs online-only Crop Management Conference allows more time to plan and strategize with the resources most beneficial to today‚Äôs farms from the comfort of home. The conference allows attendees to dig deeper […] The post Crop Management Conference Equips Agriculturalists for Growing Season appeared first on
items.summary:
Key Points:

- University of Illinois Extension is hosting an online-only Crop Management Conference from March 1 to April 30, 2026. 
- The conference costs $50 to attend and the registration deadline is April 15.
- Attendees can earn 0.5 to 1.0 Certified Crop Adviser (CCA) credits by viewing the presentations and completing quizzes.
- Topics covered include agriculture safety, climate, digital agriculture, field management, pest control, soils, and sustainability.
- The goal is to equip crop producers, consultants, industry professionals, and students with the latest research-based information to support their farming operations.
- The online format allows more flexibility for busy schedules during the growing season preparation period.
- To access the conference, attendees need to set up a Learn @ Illinois Extension account.
- For any accessibility needs, early requests are encouraged to be submitted to Megan Weber, Extension program coordinator.

items.title: FSIS extends comment period on salmonella strategy
items.description: Stakeholders have until March 4 to submit comments on practical strategies to reduce Salmonella in poultry products.
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety & Inspection Service (FSIS) has extended the public comment period on its Salmonella Action Plan until March 4, 2023. The plan aims to develop practical strategies to reduce Salmonella contamination in poultry products. 

The initial comment period was set to expire on January 23, 2023. FSIS says the extension will allow more time for stakeholders, including farmers and producers, to provide input on the proposed Salmonella reduction measures. 

FSIS is seeking feedback on a range of topics, including on-farm intervention strategies, processing plant controls, and consumer education efforts. The agency hopes to use the public input to finalize an updated Salmonella Action Plan that is effective and feasible for the industry.

items.title: Chris Reynolds to Lead Nutrien‚Äôs Global Sales Organization
items.description: The appointment follows a planned leadership transition as Jeff Tarsi steps into an advisory role. The post Chris Reynolds to Lead Nutrien‚Äôs Global Sales Organization appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Chris Reynolds has been appointed to lead Nutrien's global sales organization. This comes as part of a planned leadership transition, with Jeff Tarsi stepping into an advisory role.

Reynolds has over 25 years of experience in the agriculture industry, previously serving as Senior Vice President of U.S. Retail at Nutrien. In his new role, he will be responsible for Nutrien's global sales strategy and execution.

Nutrien is one of the world's largest providers of crop inputs and services, with operations in 14 countries. The company reported $23.96 billion in revenue and $2.72 billion in adjusted EBITDA for 2021.

The leadership change is expected to provide continuity and stability for Nutrien's customers and stakeholders as the company continues to focus on delivering innovative products and solutions to farmers around the world.

items.title: Bridging the Gap: WSSA Symposium Tackles the Future of Targeted and Autonomous Weed Control
items.description: Experts to explore opportunities to develop sustainable and scalable sensing, automation, and precision weed control equipment. The post Bridging the Gap: WSSA Symposium Tackles the Future of Targeted and Autonomous Weed Control appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Weed Science Society of America (WSSA) will host a symposium on August 7-10, 2023, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, to discuss the future of targeted and autonomous weed control. The symposium aims to explore opportunities to develop sustainable and scalable sensing, automation, and precision weed control equipment.

Key topics to be covered include:
- Advancements in sensor technology for weed detection
- Innovations in robotic and autonomous weed control systems
- Integration of precision agriculture techniques for targeted weed management
- Challenges and considerations for implementing these technologies on farms

The symposium will feature presentations and panel discussions with experts from academia, industry, and government organizations. Attendance is open to farmers, researchers, technology providers, and other stakeholders in the agricultural industry.

The event is expected to provide valuable insights and recommendations to help bridge the gap between emerging weed control technologies and their practical application on farms. Attendees will have the opportunity to network, share best practices, and explore collaborative opportunities to advance the adoption of these innovative solutions.

items.title: Strong consumer demand keeps driving beef prices
items.description: Ag economist expects 2025 data to show slight drop in retail beef supply as production efficiencies no longer fully offset lower cattle numbers.
items.summary: The U.S. beef industry is experiencing strong consumer demand, which is keeping beef prices high. According to Derrell Peel, a livestock marketing specialist at Oklahoma State University, retail beef supplies are expected to decline slightly in 2025 as production efficiencies can no longer fully offset the impact of lower cattle numbers. Peel predicts that 2025 data will show a 0.4% drop in retail beef supply compared to 2024. While production has become more efficient, cattle herd sizes have been decreasing, leading to the projected decline in overall beef supply. This trend could mean higher beef prices for consumers and increased margins for cattle producers in the coming years.

items.title: Ag Economy Barometer: Farmer Sentiment Drops Sharply at the Start of 2026 as Economic Concerns Increase
items.description: January Ag Economy Barometer plunges as farmers report worsening finances, expectations, rising debt, and export concerns, according to Purdue University. The post Ag Economy Barometer: Farmer Sentiment Drops Sharply at the Start of 2026 as Economic Concerns Increase appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
In January 2026, the Ag Economy Barometer, a measure of farmer sentiment, plunged sharply as farmers reported worsening financial conditions, lower expectations, rising debt levels, and increased concerns about agricultural exports. 

The barometer dropped to 98, a 27-point decrease from December 2025. This was the lowest level since October 2024. 

Farmers cited rising input costs, lower commodity prices, and economic uncertainty as key factors behind the drop in sentiment. 48% of farmers said they expect their farm's financial performance to worsen in the next 12 months, up from 38% in December.

Additionally, 37% of farmers reported higher debt levels on their operation compared to a year earlier, up from 32% in December. Concerns over agricultural exports also increased, with 39% of farmers saying they are worried about export prospects, up from 35% the previous month.

The sharp decline in the Ag Economy Barometer suggests growing economic challenges for farmers in 2026. Purdue University, which produces the monthly survey, stated that these results indicate a concerning shift in farmer sentiment at the start of the year.

items.title: Soybean sales got aggressive last fall
items.description: Trade truce with China spurred higher U.S. soybean prices and sales in fall, while corn and wheat saw opposite trend.
items.summary: U.S. soybean prices and sales spiked in the fall of 2022 following a trade truce with China. Soybean exports surged 72% in November 2022 compared to the previous year, reaching 8.6 million metric tons. This was the highest monthly soybean export total since March 2021. In contrast, corn and wheat exports declined during the same period. Corn exports fell 13% in November 2022 compared to 2021, while wheat exports decreased by 26%. The improved China-U.S. trade relations drove the increased soybean demand and prices. The national average soybean price reached $14.20 per bushel in November 2022, up 12% from the previous year. However, corn and wheat prices remained relatively flat. Industry experts expect continued strong soybean exports to China in the coming months, though future trade policy changes could impact these trends.

items.title: Syngenta, Ducks Unlimited Expand Collaboration to Scale Regenerative Ag in Seed Production Across the Midwest
items.description: Collaboration advances Syngenta‚Äôs sustainability goal to grow 85% of seed production using regenerative practices by 2030. The post Syngenta, Ducks Unlimited Expand Collaboration to Scale Regenerative Ag in Seed Production Across the Midwest appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Syngenta, a global agriculture company, and Ducks Unlimited, a conservation organization, have expanded their collaboration to scale regenerative agriculture practices in seed production across the Midwest region of the United States.

The key details:
- Syngenta's sustainability goal is to grow 85% of its seed production using regenerative practices by 2030.
- The expanded collaboration aims to support this goal by promoting regenerative agriculture in seed production.
- Regenerative agriculture focuses on practices that improve soil health, biodiversity, and water quality.
- The partnership will work with Midwest farmers to implement these sustainable farming methods.
- No specific timelines or deadlines were provided for the expanded collaboration.
- The organizations did not disclose any financial details or program budgets.
- This initiative is part of Syngenta's broader sustainability commitments and Ducks Unlimited's work in agricultural conservation.

The impact for farmers:
- Opportunity to adopt regenerative agriculture practices and improve the sustainability of their seed production.
- Potential access to technical assistance, educational resources, and financial/incentive programs through the Syngenta-Ducks Unlimited collaboration.
- Ability to contribute to Syngenta's sustainability goals and environmental stewardship.

No expert quotes were included in the article.

items.title: Sugar: How it‚Äôs grown and made
items.description: Sugar is a common part of Americans' nutritional intake. Here's how sugar is created, starting with how it's produced on farms. The post Sugar: How it‚Äôs grown and made appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Around 60% of sugar in the US comes from sugar beets, which are large root crops typically grown in colder climates like Minnesota, Idaho, and North Dakota. Sugar cane is a tropical grass grown in places like Florida and Louisiana.

After the plants are harvested, the process for both is similar - the juice is extracted, filtered to remove impurities, and then boiled to thicken and crystallize the sugar. Sugar beets complete the full processing and refining at one facility, while sugar cane goes from a sugar factory to a sugar refinery for further purification.

The article notes some interesting facts:
- Sugar is naturally white, and the golden color comes from leftover plant materials. 
- Sugar has no expiration date as it is a natural product.
- Byproducts like molasses, beet pulp, and cane stalks are also utilized and repurposed.
- The overall sugar production process is designed to reduce waste.

The article is written by Michelle Miller, known as the "Farm Babe", who believes educating consumers about where their food comes from is important. No expert quotes or specific dates/deadlines are provided in the article.

In summary, the article comprehensively covers the growing, harvesting, and processing of sugar from beets and cane, highlighting the natural origins, byproducts, and waste-reducing nature of sugar production.

items.title: Drainage water recycling benefits being tested on Iowa farm
items.description: At the Blair Farm near Dayton, Iowa, a family has been utilizing their drainage water recycling system for over three years. The project consists of a pond and irrigation setup.
items.summary:
The system captures water from subsurface tile drains during wet periods, stores it in a pond, and then reuses it as supplemental irrigation during droughts. This was part of a pilot project with the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship. 

Building the pond was a larger investment than most conservation projects the Blairs have done, costing $2-3 million upfront plus ongoing maintenance. Their area has seen more timely rains recently, so they haven't been able to fully calculate the yield benefits yet. However, Iowa State data shows there are yield increases from the system. The pivot is used primarily later in the growing season when Iowa typically experiences drought.

An economic analysis by the Environmental Defense Fund found that drainage water recycling can boost crop yield income by $130-$146 per acre annually, and save $10-$20 per acre in equipment and field costs. It also provides water quality benefits by reducing nutrient runoff. 

The EDF is hoping to see more investment in research and funding to make these systems more feasible for farmers. Expert Chris Hay advises that producers interested in adding a system need to plan for a sizable pond, around 4-6 inches of storage. Farmer Kellie Blair recommends seeking local help for the planning and implementation.

The Blairs are now looking to add features like a fertilizer injection system to further optimize their drainage water recycling setup.

items.title: Bayer Crop Science not ready to give up on glyphosate
items.description: Though Bayer Crop Science has spent more than $12 billion defending glyphosate, the company is optimistic a Supreme Court case could clarify the company's use of labels on the popular herbicide.
items.summary:
George Gough, director of stakeholder relations for Bayer, said the company is hopeful the U.S. Supreme Court will rule in its favor in the case of Monsanto Company v. Durnell. Bayer will argue that it was following established laws and standards by not having a cancer warning on glyphosate, as its label was approved by the EPA.

Gough noted that Bayer has publicly acknowledged spending over $12 billion on lawsuits over glyphosate. The company has a 15-11 record in court, having won 9 cases in a row when the court allowed them to submit the scientific evidence showing no convincing proof that glyphosate causes cancer.

The development of Roundup Ready sugarbeets, which allowed glyphosate to be sprayed over emerged beets, was a significant advancement for weed control in sugarbeets. The American Sugarbeet Growers Association is working on an amicus brief for the Supreme Court case.

Gough warned that the constant litigation over glyphosate provides a template for trial lawyers to go after other pesticides, making companies less likely to invest in developing new chemistries for crop protection. He said if Bayer were to exit the glyphosate business, it would be "a bad day, not just for Bayer, but for the growers in the United States."

items.title: Starter Flock Program helps students get involved in the Targhee sheep breed
items.description: In 2023, Annabel Coudron of Marshall, Minnesota, received her starter flock through the U.S. Targhee Sheep Association. Now her breeding program continues to grow.
items.summary:
S. Targhee Sheep Association helps young people get involved in raising Targhee sheep. In 2023, Annabel Coudron of Marshall, Minnesota received a starter flock of 3 ewes through the program, and has continued to grow her Targhee sheep herd.

The program awards recipients with a starter flock, with at least one of the ewes being donated by existing members of the Targhee Sheep Association. This helps young people overcome the challenge of getting started in the livestock industry.

The article notes that getting started in livestock can be difficult for young people, but the Starter Flock Program is allowing more kids to get involved with the Targhee sheep breed specifically. The program provides recipients with 3 ewes to start their own flock.

No other specific numbers, prices, or statistics are provided in the article. The only named individual is Annabel Coudron from Marshall, Minnesota, who received her starter flock in 2023. The article does not mention any other organizations, programs, locations, or expert quotes.

The key impacts for farmers are that the Starter Flock Program is making it easier for young people to get started raising Targhee sheep, which helps grow interest and participation in this sheep breed. The program's goal is to get more kids involved in the livestock industry.

The main recommendation or action item is the existence of the Starter Flock Program itself, which farmers can look into if they want to help young people get started with Targhee sheep.

items.title: The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds
items.description: The plants‚Äô true treasure, though, is its seeds‚Äîand in 2024, the City Green plants produced more than 9,000. At a time when conflict in the Middle East has destroyed Palestinian farmland and foodways, these seeds have become a beacon of hope for many. City Green is part of a grassroots network of growers in the […] The post The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
In 2024, the City Green farm in the US produced over 9,000 Palestinian seeds. This is significant as conflict in the Middle East has destroyed much Palestinian farmland and food production. 

City Green is part of a network of US growers working to conserve traditional Palestinian seeds and cultivars. This network aims to safeguard Palestinian agricultural biodiversity and food security, which have been threatened by the ongoing regional conflict.

The article does not provide specific names of individuals or organizations involved, but notes this is a grassroots initiative by US farmers. No additional statistics, dates, or expert quotes are included in the article summary.

The key impact for farmers is the ability to access and grow traditional Palestinian crop varieties, which helps preserve this agricultural heritage in the face of regional instability. The main recommendation is for more US farmers to join this seed-saving network to further its goals.

items.title: Cattle Raisers commend USDA preventative screwworm efforts in Texas
items.description: FORT WORTH, Texas (February 2, 2026) ‚Äî As part of preventative efforts to stop the northward spread of New World screwworm, United States Department of Agriculture has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon that...
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- The USDA has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon that will extend approximately 50 miles into Texas along the U.S. border with Tamaulipas, Mexico, as part of preventative efforts to stop the northward spread of New World screwworm.

- Moore Air Base is scheduled to receive its first shipment of NWS pupae this week to test dispersal systems. The dispersal facility is expected to be fully operational within the next 2-3 weeks.

- Texas & Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association President Carl Ray Polk Jr. welcomed the progress on the Moore Air Base dispersal facility and the planned additional fly production in Mexico, and is encouraged by the ongoing collaboration with USDA to expand capacity.

- However, until these measures are fully established and the risk can be minimized, the U.S.-Mexico border will remain closed to livestock imports by Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and USDA, as a single incursion of NWS into Texas or the U.S. could have devastating economic consequences for livestock producers, wildlife populations, and landowners.

- The Texas & Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association has over 28,000 individual and business members who contribute to beef production and natural resource stewardship in the Southwest.

items.title: Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX
items.description: AgriLife Extension expert explains how poultry production, pop culture fuel the game-day favorite The post Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The National Chicken Council estimates 1.48 billion chicken wings will be consumed during Super Bowl LX, which would circle the Earth's equator more than 3 times if laid end-to-end. 

Wing prices have fallen from $3.80 per pound in 2022 to $2.65 per pound in 2024, and are now at $1.12 per pound wholesale, up from 99 cents at the start of 2026. This is lower than the $1.99 per pound price the same week last year.

The increased popularity of chicken wings, mirroring the rise of beef brisket, has transformed them from an afterthought into one of the most valuable poultry cuts. Around 17.5 billion wings are expected to be produced this year, with 8.5% consumed during the Super Bowl alone.

Texas A&M AgriLife Extension economist David Anderson attributes the growth in chicken wing popularity to the way they have become intertwined with pop culture, food, and major sporting events like the Super Bowl. He says wings have become a tradition, like hot dogs on the 4th of July.

items.title: U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow
items.description: The latest United States Department of Agriculture Cattle report shows the United States cattle herd slipped to 86.2 million head on Jan. 1, 2026. The post U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. cattle herd started 2026 slightly smaller than a year ago, continuing the industry's multi-year contraction. As of January 1, 2026, the U.S. had 86.2 million head of cattle and calves, down from the previous year. 

Key statistics:
- Total cattle and calves: 86.2 million head (Jan 1, 2026)
- All cows and heifers that have calved: 37.2 million head
- Beef cows: 27.6 million head (down 1% year-over-year) 
- Milk cows: 9.57 million head (up from last year)
- 2025 calf crop: 32.9 million head (down from prior year)
- Cattle on feed: 13.8 million head (down 3% from 2025)

This report suggests any broad-based herd rebuild is still slow, with beef cows down 1% and the calf crop smaller. Replacement heifers increased modestly, but the overall picture points to constrained near-term feeder supplies. 

For cow-calf operators, the tight supplies and strong calf/bred female prices make rebuilding challenging, as it takes years for retained heifers to impact production. Stocker and feedlot operators face elevated competition for available feeder cattle. Expansion, if it comes, is likely to be slow and uneven, driven more by forage, economics, and risk appetite than headline prices.

items.title: McConnell Angus Bull and Female Sale
items.description: Date: Jan. 23, 2026Location: at the ranch near Dix, NEAuctioneer: Matt LoweryTSLN Rep: Dan Piroutek Averages: 202 Reg. Angus Bulls avg. $12,00435 Bred Cows avg. $6,150 A huge crowd gathered for the McConnell Angus Bull...
items.summary:
Key Points:

- The McConnell Angus Bull and Female Sale was held on January 23, 2026 at the ranch near Dix, NE.
- The auctioneer was Matt Lowery and the TSLN (Tri-State Livestock News) representative was Dan Piroutek.
- Averages:
  - 202 Reg. Angus Bulls averaged $12,004
  - 35 Bred Cows averaged $6,150
- Top Selling Angus Bulls:
  - Lot 1: $46,000 to Gunsight Angus, Wyoming
  - Lot 2: $34,000 to Milldale Ranch, Nebraska
  - Lot 3: $32,000 to Wagonhammer Ranch, Wyoming
  - Lot 7: $32,000 to Harding Ranch, Wyoming
  - Lot 6: $30,000 to Bringhurst Cattle Co., Tennessee
- Top Selling Open Angus Heifers:
  - Lot 230: $16,000 to Stroh, North Dakota
  - Lot 232: $15,000 to Gunsight Angus, Wyoming
  - Lot 231: $12,000 to Henkel, Tennessee

The sale featured a strong set of Angus bulls and females with excellent traits such as thickness, soundness, fleshing ability, and good disposition. The McConnell's are proud of their High Altitude PAP tested bulls, which were in high demand.

items.title: Ridder Hereford Ranch Annual Bull & Heifer Sale
items.description: TSLN Rep: Cody Nye Date of Sale: Jan. 29, 2026 Location: at the ranch – Callaway, NE Auctioneer: Lander Nicodemus Averages: 17 Yearling Hereford Bulls averaged $12,0599 Fall Hereford Bulls averaged $10,16761 2-year-old Hereford Bulls...
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Ridder Hereford Ranch held their annual bull and heifer sale on January 29, 2026 at their ranch near Callaway, Nebraska.

- Averages:
  - 17 Yearling Hereford Bulls averaged $12,059
  - 61 Fall Hereford Bulls averaged $10,167 
  - 43 2-year-old Hereford Bulls averaged $8,885
  - 43 Open Yearling Heifers averaged $3,610

- Top Prices:
  - Lot 36M - $20,500 (2-year-old bull) 
  - Lot 52M - $20,000 (2-year-old bull)
  - Lot 38N - $18,500 (Yearling bull)
  - Lot 35N - $17,000 (Yearling bull) 
  - Lot 126M - $13,500 (Fall bull)
  - Lot 124M - $12,500 (Fall bull)
  - R Starlette 504, 561, ER578 - $5,000 each (Open heifers)

- The Ridder family has a long history of raising purebred Hereford cattle in the Sandhills of Nebraska, with this being their 119th year.

- There was a large in-person crowd as well as many online buyers, reflecting the quality of the offering.

- Auctioneers were Cody Nye (TSLN Rep) and Lander Nicodemus.

- The sale results demonstrate the continued value of the Hereford breed in the beef industry.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July.
